byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and JACKIE CALMES

docs.lead_paragraph: Allan W. Russell, a 78-year-old retiree from Leesburg, Ga., had attended his congressman's town-hall-style meeting in Albany, Ga., last month because of his concerns about health care. He did not take well to Mr. Obama's characterizations of the opposition to his plan. ''He went quickly to blaming those of us who questioned what was taking place, of using scare tactics and not caring what will happen to those without insurance,'' Mr. Russell wrote. ''He was less than subtle in his suggestion that those who raise questions are uncaring, unthinking individuals with malice in their hearts.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Roger A. Rosenblatt, 64, is the director of the Rural/Underserved Opportunities Program at the University of Washington School of Medicine. The program sends rising second-year students to practice primary care in needy communities for a month each summer. ''As a family physician and medical educator for the last 35 years, I have waited a long time for our country to provide a medical care system that works for all the members of our society,'' Dr. Rosenblatt wrote. ''President Obama's approach is based on common sense: our nation's health depends as much on an inclusive and effective health care system for everyone as the health of our children depends upon their being able to get medical care when and where they need it. The time has come to realize that we are all in this together, and that health of each individual depends on the well-being of all of us.''
docs.abstract: Dr Roger A Rosenblatt, in e-mail, comments on Pres Obama's speech on health care reforms

docs.lead_paragraph: Elaine H. Carl, 72, who lives at the Sunrise Lakes retirement village in Sunrise, Fla., said she liked ''part of his speech'' but did not think that Americans should be required to buy insurance. Ms. Carl said some of her fears about Medicare had been at least temporarily soothed. ''I do believe what he's saying, that nothing will be taken from us,'' she wrote. ''But I don't know; I still have my qualms. It's so easy to say one thing and then turn around and do another. People have been hurt so many times by listening to what has been promised, and they end up in a sinkhole. I'm still very much afraid. I don't know where the money is going to come from to pay for all of these things.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Kylie G. Boggess, 24, of Twin Falls, Idaho, is a second-year medical student at the University of Washington who hopes to practice primary care. ''When President Obama came out and said that he wants to be the last president to address the health care issue, he commanded a level of confidence and created a sense of urgency that he has lacked while campaigning for health care this year,'' Ms. Boggess wrote.
